dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A traffic collision...Why can’t we say ‘accident’ again?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Because ‘accident’ implies there’s no one to blame.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: What about him? Oh, put a sock in it town mouse!

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, you want to be a big cop ina small town, bugger off up the model village. The ANDES sit in their office eating ice-cream. DANNY ent with another bowl, which ANGEL declines.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, things aren’t always simple as they look.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: But most times they are. Let’s wait until Er. Hatchet comes back with something, before you go jumping the Kalashnikov.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Well, in the meantime, why not start by checking out some of Martin Blower’s clients?  62.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Martin Blower represents damn near most of the village. You want us to go through the whole phone book?

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’1l put a call into Aaron A. Aarronson shall we?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Please don’t be childish. At least think about interviewing the widow? Mr Blower was clearly having an affair with Eve Draper.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: And how did you establish that? DANNY slams his [U+FB02]st on the table. ANGEL jumps.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We sat through three hours of so-called acting last night. The kiss was the only convincing moment in it. DANNY [U+FBO2]ashes a grin at a bemused ANGEL.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Alright, pipe down.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, what else you got, Tango and Hutch?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Simon Skinner.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: He was acting suspiciously at the collision scene.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: He runs the local supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Anything else?  63.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Skid marks.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Now who’s being childish?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: There were no skid marks at the scene. Don’t you think it’s a little strange that Mr. Blower would lose control of the car and not think to apply his brakes? For the [U+FBO2]rst time, the ANDES do not have an answer ANGEL (cont’d) If there are no skid marks it follows that for three hundred yards the driver and the passenger made no attempt to prevent their fate. You don’t have to be a detective to work that out.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah! FRANK pops into the office. He’s also eating ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You causing trouble?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I was talking to the ‘detectives’ about the ‘accident’.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: "Yeah’.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Dreadful business. You free?

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes they are.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Good. Got a spot of bother up at Ellroy Farm. Old Arthur Webley’s been clipping hedgerows that don’t belong to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes sir?  64.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: You wanted grass roots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY drives a pissed off ANGEL up a dirt road. P.C. BOB WALKER is in the back. SAXON drools on ANGELS shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Why do We used the dog?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s not the dog we need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A White haired Did farmer, ARTHUR WEBLEY stands at his do with a shotgun broken over his arm.

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY
dialogues.text: Hedgizuhedgeinnit. loonlychopped etdowwnoozicoutn’tseethe View nomore. Wasshemoaninabout?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Right. (to Danny and Walker) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: PC WALKER
dialogues.text: Eessad. A hedgeisahedge innit. Nee onlychoppedet dowwn cozee cun’t see t’voo nomore. Whas he moanin’ about?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Right. (to Danny) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He said a hedge is a hedge. He only chopped it down because it spoilt his view. What’s Reaper moaning about?  65.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Right. That’s not the point Mr. Webley.

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY
dialogues.text: Whystoyalwaspiokinawnmeanywaiz. Iznotthewanrunninabowtallhowersofthenight. Themhloodyoods.

dialogues.speaker: PC WALKER
dialogues.text: Eesad. Why you pickin onhem. Ees nart the wan runnnin abowt all hours like them bloody hoods.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Them bloody who?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hoods.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What does he mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Probably them kids.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Webley, I appreciate your position but you can’t go around cutting down other people’s hedges without permission.

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY
dialogues.text: Yarghspose.

dialogues.speaker: PC WALKER
dialogues.text: ‘'Yargh he suppose’.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: ‘Yeah I suppose’.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Thank you

dialogues.speaker: DANNY/WALKER/WEBLEY
dialogues.text: S’alroight.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (points at shotgun) Oh and Mr. Webley, I trust you have a license for that?  66.

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY
dialogues.text: Oharrghldozfortheesun.

dialogues.speaker: PC WALKER
dialogues.text: ‘Idoes for theesun’.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He does for this one.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean by ‘this one’? ANGEL and DANNY peer in as WEBLEY opens the door to a hug outbuilding. The daylight illuminates...an enormous arsen of antique firearms; RIFLES, SHOTGUNS, PISTOLS, BLUNDERBUSSES. It’s a museum of firepower.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: By the power of Grey Skull!

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Where on Earth did you get these?

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY DANNY
dialogues.text: Foundum. Found ‘em. ANGEL (cont’d) And what is that? ANGEL points to an enormous spiky sphere in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY WEBLEY
dialogues.text: Sea mine. Seemoine. ANGEL (cont’d) Well Mr. Webley, this is an extremely dangerous collection. It’s a wonder nobody’s been hurt before.

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY
dialogues.text: Naaarrrgh. Iss jussaloodajunk. WEBLEY strikes the SEA MINE with his walking stick. ANGEL and DANNY’s faces go white. There is a resounding clang..  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL, DANNY and WEELEY come bursting out of the shed. Th run in heroic slow motion towards a nearby hedge. All thr dive over the hedge and land with an enormous crunch. Seconds pass...Nothing...ANGEL and DANNY stand. They peer over the hedge. More seconds pass... Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SQUAD CAR/FARM
dialogues.text: ANGEL is sat in the squad car on the radio. Behind, WEBLE and DANNY stand with the sea mine.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Apparently it’s deactivated.

dialogues.speaker: WEBLEY
dialogues.text: (hits the seamine) Thassroit. Deeaaktiyaded.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s not live.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (kicks seamine) Looks live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHCUTS; ANGEL and DANNY march in with armfuls of guns, the curly haired DESK SERGEANT tags them, the evidence ro is filled (with the SEA MINE is stored on a high shelf}.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: That was a quite an impressive haul today, Constable Butterman.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe we should do something to celebrate...unless you have to water your Peace Lily.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What are you thinking exactly?  68.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CROWN " NIGHT
dialogues.text: The pub is heaving with a huge cross section of people; Neighbourhood Watch, off duty police, even FRANK.

dialogues.speaker: MARY PORTER
dialogues.text: Right you are my love.

dialogues.speaker: ROY PORTER
dialogues.text: Yes sir, what can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Pint of lager, please Roy. And what can I get you that isn’t a cranberry juice?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I don’t really want to get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You can get a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Okay I’1l have one.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m talking about!

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What’s your wine selection?

dialogues.speaker: RUY PORTER
dialogues.text: Oh, we’ve got red...or white.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Pint of lager, please Roy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeaaaah Roy. ANGEL spies the ANDES at the bar and wanders over.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Any developments from this morning?

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, CSI found nothing, Dr. Hatcher reported no misadventure, Mrs. Blower has four alibis.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: And Skinner?  ANGEL and 69.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: He runs the local supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Come on Sergeant, it’s not your job to investigate this incident is it? Is it?

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT AND CARTWRIGET
dialogues.text: No it isn’t. DANNY sit down. ANGEL scribbles in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You don’t switch off do you?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You sound like my ex.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why, did she have a deep voice?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, she always used to accuse me of not being able to switch off.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well you are always thinking away.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: It’s what I do.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, no I think it’s amazing. I mean what made you want to hea policeman-

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Officer -

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What made you want to bea policeman-officer?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I can’t remember a time when I didn’t want to he a police officer apart from the summer of 1979 when I wanted to be Kermit The Frog. It all started with my Uncle Derek. He was a Sergeant in the Net. Gave me a police pedal car when I was five. I rode it around every moment I was (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL (cont’d) awake, arresting kids twice my size for littering and spitting. I got beaten up a lot but it didn’t stop me. I wanted to be like Uncle Derek.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sounds like a good bloke.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Actually, he was jailed for selling drugs to students.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What a cunt.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: He most likely bought the pedal car with the proceeds. Needless to say I never went near it again. I let it rust. But I never forgot that clear sense of right and wrong I felt at the wheel of that pedal car and I refused to accept that corruption was the inevitable consequence of authority. I had to prove to myself that the law could be proper and righteous and for the good of humankind. I knew then, I was destined to be a police officer.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Shame.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I think you would’ve made a great muppet. ANGEL laughs. It’s the first time we have seen him do thi

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: So, what made you want to be a police officer?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad does it...I think after Mum died, it’s what he wanted. Keep me close by.  71.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I ask how she died?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Traffic collision.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Aw, don’t worry...watch this. DANNY sticks a fork in his eye, scarlet squirts everywher

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ta-daaaa! DANNY reveals a TOMATO KETCHUP sachet. ANGEL laughs. DANNY (cont’d) Get ‘em in silly bollocks... FLASH CUTS. The night wears on. The glasses on the table multiply. DANNY and ANGEL are both tipsy and enjoy each other’s company. DANNY beats ANGEL at bar skittles. LATER. ANGEL finds his way to the bar. He sees a beaming SIMON SKINNER sitting at the bar with another gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Ah, 777. Do join us. You’ve met George Merchant haven’t you? GEORGE MERCHANT is drunk and morose. ANGEL sits at the ba

dialogues.speaker: MRCHANT
dialogues.text: Good evening offisher...

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: We were just talking about the accident. Dreadful business.

dialogues.speaker: MRCHANT
dialogues.text: I’d come to know Martin and Eve very well of late. Such a losssh.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: What say we drink to their demise?  72.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Isn’t it drink to their memory?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Of course. Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE MERCHANT
dialogues.text: I mussh go to the little boyssh room. MERCHANT gets off his stool. He is remarkably short.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Little being the operative word. He’1l be in bits tomerrow. SKINNER moves off. ANGEL watches him go, swivelling on hi stool. It’s a cool mement. Until ANGEL slips off his seat

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Think somebedy needs to go home.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m not that drunk sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Net yen. Him. FRANK points to GEORGE MERCHANT who stands in the corner, with his nob out, pissing into the coin tray of a fruit machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY carry GEORGE MERCHANT along the street. H is unconscious, his feet not touching the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey, we did get a little drunk. Geddit? It’s funny ‘cos he’s little. ANGEL spies the HOODIES huddled round a village map. He gestures for DANNY te be quiet and sneaks ever.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Evening all. The HOODIES spin around and freeze. A freshly sprayed grefitti tag is en the village map. ANGEL holds out his hand.  73. ANGEL (cont’d) Give it here. A SPRAY CAN sails past ANGEL’s head and hits GEORGE MERCH full in the face. He and DANNY fell to the [U+FBO2]eor. The HOODIES scatter. ANGEL steams over, grabbing HOODIE 1 and pulling him back into a neerby bin. ANGEL grabs HOODI and spins him round, pulling the hood off his face. ANGEL finds himself face to face with the BLONDE SCHOOLKI HOODIE 1 meanwhile, clambers out of the bin and runs off. A thrown ANGEL looks on, as the BLONDE SCHOOLKID [U+FB02] his hood back up and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let em go. They’1l come round again. ANGEL and DANNY pick MERCHANT up and carry him eff.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: We know where his house is right?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY stops, looking up at the monstreus piece ef architecture.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Gcod grief.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Six mohths ago, that was a pear orcherd.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I want to threw up, but I fear it may add value. MERCHANT is suddenly awake. His eyes glazed.

dialogues.speaker: MERCHANT
dialogues.text: Jussst here. How much do I owe youss?  74.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Twenty quid. MERCHANT gives DANNY £20 guid. ANGEL gives it back.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Thank you and here’s your change.

dialogues.speaker: MERCHANT
dialogues.text: Buh-bye. MERCHANT disappears inside. ANGEL and DANNY walk away.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t want to be him in the morning. They walk out of shot, revealing...A CLOAKED FIGURE! EXT. GEORGE NERCHANT’S HOUSE - NIGHT A light [U+FB02]icks on. We see GEORGE MERCHANT stumbling around his hall. We also the CLOAKED FIGURE watching, waiting... EXT. DANNY’S HOUSE - NIGHT DANNY and ANGEL arrive at DANNY’s front door.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, this is me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I shall see you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Unless you wanna come in for a coffee?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I don’t drink coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, no caffeine after midday.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How about another beer?  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fridge opens...We see a number of bottled beers... GEORGE MERCHANT grabs a beer and swigs it as he staggers the toilet. Outside the CLOAKED FIGURE watches. MERCHANT put his beer on the cistern and has a piss...He [U+FBO2]ushes, zips up and retrieves his beer from the cistern. As he stands back up, behind him we see... The CLOAKED EIGUEE. Who strikes him with a cudgel. Bang! INT. DANNY’S HOUSE - NIGHT ANGEL drops down onto DANNY’s sofa and surveys the untidy room. DANNY appears to be living out of cardboard boxes.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: When did you move in? DANNY enters from the kitchen with two cans of beer.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: About five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You should get some pot plants.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve been tending my Peace Lily for three years now. NASA rates it as one of top ten air cleaning plants. It oxygenates the room, it helps me think, it relieves stress. Its needs are simple. Janine said I loved my Lily more than her.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Is that why you split up?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Cos’ you dunnit with a plant.  76.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, it was more about being obsessed with the job.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But, that’s good though innit?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I did miss a few dinners, parties, a birthday or two-

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well I mean-

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: -her dad’s funeral. I just want to be good at what I do.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You are good at what you do. You’ve just got to learn to switch off that big melon.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You know Danny, I don’t know how.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’11 show you how. DANNY opens a cupboard that is stacked full of alphabetiz VHS tapes. It’s the most ordered area of the entire (U+FBO2]at.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: By the power of Greyskull. DANNY carefully selects two tapes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Point Break or Bad Boys 2?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Which one do you think I’1l1 prefer?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I mean which one do you wanna watch first?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You are pulling my leg?  77. INT. GEDRGE MERCHANT’S KITCHEN - NIGHT MERCHANT is dragged by his feet and dumped into a kitchen chair...GLOVED HANDS empty beans into a pan... Bacon is fried...Gas taps are turned on full...Gas hisses... INT. DANNY’S HGUSE - NIGHT Static hisses as the video [U+FBO2]ickers to life.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: This film is A-MAZING!

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: So, what’s it actually about?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: An FBI agent who goes under cover to infiltrate a gang of wild wave riding, sky diving, bank robbers but falls in love with the surfing lifestyle and the leader’s girlfriend and ends up having to make some very tough choices.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: So it’s based on a true story?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Now that I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No I just mean, it sounds a little far fetched.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a film innit? INT. GEORGE MERCHANT’S HOUSE - NIGHT Hiss...GLOVED HANDS light a candle in the living room. Hiss...MEECHANT lies motionless in the chair....Hiss... INT. DANNY’S HOUSE - NIGHT DANNY and ANGEL are on the sofa. ‘Point Break’ ends.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Whaddya think?  78.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Well, I won’t argue that it’s a no holds barred, adrenaline fuelled thrill ride but there’s no way you could perpetrate that amount of carnage and mayhem without incurring a considerable amount of paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s nothing man. This is about to go off! EXT. GEDRGE MERCHANT’S HOUSE - NIGHT KA-BOOOOOOM. MERGHANT’s [U+FB02]aming body [U+FB02]ies th the air. INT. DANNY’S HOUSE - EARLY MORNING DANNY’s head rests on ANGEL as they sleep on the sofa. Daylight fills the room as ’Bad Boys 2’ blares from the T

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: This shit just got real! The phone rings. They open their eyes at the same time. EXT. GEDRGE MERCHANT’S HOUSE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCHER
dialogues.text: Nasty way to go. The Sandford Police survey the smoking black husk of Merchant’s house. His twisted and burnt cadaver is covere up by DR. HATCHER. Paramedics carry him off on a gurney. DR. HATCHER (CONT’D) Seems Mr. Merchant tried to have a little fry up and left the gas on. They say you shouldn’t eat late at night.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS THATCHER
dialogues.text: I dunno. I like a little midnight gobble. THATCHER and WALKER laugh at this. WALKER mumbles ‘Cocks’  79.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: So what do we reckon? Angel? FISHER looks to a spectacularly groggy ANGEL and DANNY.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Help me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: We should set up a proper cordon, keep people back, let the fire crew finish and get the forensics to do a thorough sweep.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Right. What he said. ANGEL spots a crew of workmen on the periphery, waiting t clear the scene. TIM MESSENGER appears, notebook in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Sergeant, a guick word?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Messenger, please. A statement will be issued shortly.

dialogues.speaker: MSSENGER
dialogues.text: Actually I just wanted to find out, ‘what’s your perfect Sunday’?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: I’11 deal with the press Sergeant. Now, my perfect Sunday would begin FISHER leads MESSENGER away. ANGEL sees SIMON SKINNER amongst a crowd of onlookers. SKINNER waves ‘hello’.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWEIGHT
dialogues.text: What you thinking? Foul play?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: We’re just waiting to speak to the last people to see Mr Merchant alive, namely Sergeant Knickerless Asswipe and Constable Fanny Butterdog.  The ANDES 80.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s us. collapse with into sniggers.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Why is this such a big joke to you? Three people have died in less than a week.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh come on Dr. Sherlock, they were accidents.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: People have accidents everyday.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Ron Spencer got his cravat caught in the mulcher the other week.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: But the victims knew each other.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Everyone knows everyone round ‘ere.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWEIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah. If you didn’t see anything suspicious, then who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOM WEAVER spools through footage on his CCTV monitors. ANGEL, DANNY, FRANK and the ANDES look on.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Bit of a blind spot I’m afraid. We’re not that well covered around George Merchant’s. We only get the very edge of the explosion.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nasty way to go.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: One thing that did catch my eye.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What’s that?  81.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: You sticking it to these herberts! WEAVER shows a replay of the drunken HOODIE fight and who with delight. The ANDES snigger. ANGEL fumes.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: This is irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: I beg to differ. It’s the closest we’ve come to nabbing the bastards.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Weaver, let’s concentrate- WEAVER pauses the tape on a blurred shot of the BLONDE KI

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Did you get a good look at this little mischief? What did he-

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Forget that, just keep looking for anything out of the ordinary in the immediate area of Mr Merchant’s residence. Make a note of any car registrations spotted in the vicinity. In partieular, look out for a Red MG, license ’SS1’.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nicholas.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can I have a mo?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’ve got to ease off on these Skinner allegations. He’s the manager of the local supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: With respect sir-  82.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Listen, you are an exceptional officer, truly exceptional, but you do have to let the Andes do their job. If there’s anything amiss, we’1l hear soon enough. Until then we have to regard these incidents as accidents.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Good boy. FRANK leaves. ANGEL looks up to the photo on the wall. It of an officer with a big bushy beard; ‘Sgt, Popwell’.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel, I think I’ve found what you’re looking for. ANGEL runs excitedly over to WEAVER’s office. The ANDES follow suit, as do DANNY and FRANK. They see CCTV footage the SWAN waddling past Merchant’s house.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Ah, there you go. It was the Swan all along.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: This is not funny Detective!

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh give over Miss Marples.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Let us do our job and you do yours.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, haven’t you got a church fete to look after?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, I have not!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Actually.  83.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lovely day for it Sergeant? A bored ANGEL patrols at a bustling fete. We see impressi [U+FBO2]oral displays and banners reading ’SAVE THE CHURC RGQE’ and promoting Sandford for ’VILLAGE OF THE YEAR’. R SHOQTER sidles up to ANGEL with a tray of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel, would your theological reservations preclude you from assisting me with the raf [U+FB02]e this afternoon? There’s a glass of Joyce Cooper’s lemonade in it for you. ANGEL takes a glass and downs it, to SHOOTER’S delight. REV. SHOOTER (CONT’D) Marvellous. ANGEL slumps into a nearby chair and surveys the fete. He sees a child messily eating a ice lolly. He looks up to s the father, SGT. FISHER doing the same. He sees DORIS THATCHER standing with two burly men, giggl at a pig being spit roasted. He sees WALKER feed candy [U+FBO2]oss to SAXON. BONG. A bell rings as LURCH plays a ’TEST YOUR STRENGTH’ game. SKINNER lurks nearby, manning a ’BASH THE RAT’ stal and staring into the distance. Thunder rumbles. ANGEL follows his gaze over to TIM MESSENGER having an animated discussion with LESLIE TILLER, the [U+FBO2]orist

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shark? ANGEL jumps. The ANDES appear, clutching cans of Cider.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Seen any murderings Nicholarse? FRANK and DANNY approach dressed in wild west gear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Come on now boys. Leave Sergeant Angel alone, he’s working.  84.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Sorry Chief, won’t waste anymore police time. The ANDES slope off, swigging their cider.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Actually Nicholas. You may as well have a break.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Great. I’ve got something to show you. ANGEL follows DANNY through the crowd until they come to stop at an AIR RIFLE RANGE, run by a smiling DR. HATCHER.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: This is a ri[U+FBO2]e range.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You’1l be really good at it.

dialogues.speaker: HATCHER
dialogues.text: Three cans wins you a squeaky bunny, five gets you a [U+FB02]oppy lion. Take out all the little people, you get to waltz off with the cuddly monkey.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I thought I made it clear to you how I felt about guns.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s only an air rilU+FBO2]e.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It is for a cuddly monkey. ANGEL grudgingly takes an air rifle. DANNY smiles expectantly. ANGEL fires, hitting every can dead centre w amazing speed. He lowers the rifle, feeling excited and unclean at once. The ANDES watch, swigging their cider.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCHER
dialogues.text: Good lord. ANGEL hands the rilU+FB02]e to an awed DANNY, who inspect it.  85.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fuck me...that was- DANNY accidentally pulls the trigger. We hear an agonized yelp. DR. HATCHER drops on the [U+FB02]oor clutching his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY walk away from the stall: ANGEL clutching the CUDDLY MONKEY, DANNY in shock. Behind a Saint John’s Ambulance team attend to DR. HATCHER, who’s in some pain.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I shot someone.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: He’s a doctor, he can deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But I’ve never shot anyone before.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Believe me Constable. It’s not something you ever get used to.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe we should go on the bouncy castle. Take our minds off it. ANGEL spies SKINNER talking heatedly with TIM MSSENGER. DANNY (cont’d) What is it? Thunder rumbles. Before ANGEL can answer, a YOUNG BOY run right into him. We see that it is the BLONDE SCHOOL KID. and ANGEL lock eyes. The boy looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Watch where you’re going. ANGEL turns to see the grandfather. WEAVER (cont’d) I do apologise for my grandson. Stand up straight Gabriel, this is Sergeant Angel.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’ve met Gabriel before actually.  86.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Oh, have you? GABRIEL looks extremely anxious. His eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes. I gave a talk at the school, didn’t I Gabriel?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Maybe we’1l get a chance to have another little chat sometime.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: I’m sure Gabriel would love that.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You have a good afternoon. WEAVER and GABRIEL walk off. GABRIEL looks back at ANGEL his expression of confusion and relief.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What was that about? Before ANGEL can answer...a breathless TIM MESSENGER appears, slamming into ANGEL.

dialogues.speaker: TIM MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel, I need to talk to you about George Merchant. Alone. It might be less conspicuous if you don’t bring the monkey.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: This man is a police officer, I’d thank you to treat him with more respect.

dialogues.speaker: TIM MSSENGER
dialogues.text: I was talking about that. nods to ANGEL’s giant CUDDLY MONKEY.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: TIM MESSENGER
dialogues.text: The churchyard. Ten minutes. ANGEL watches MESSENGER scurry off, passing SIMON SKINNER  87.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Bash the rat?

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER, (TANNOY)
dialogues.text: Could we have Sergeant Angel to the stage please? ANGEL gives the CUDDLY MONKEY to DANNY and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distracted ANGEL takes to a makeshift stage where the R SHOOTER stands with a tombola and a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: Here to announce the winners is the newest addition to the Sandford Police Force-

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (under breath} Police service.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: -Sergeant Nicholas Angel.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Hello. A buzz of feedback from the mic. ANGEL eyes the clock. It 3pm. The tombola spins... ...MESSENGER waits in the churchyard, looks at his watch. ...ANGEL picks a name from the tombola. ANGEL (cont’d) The [U+FB02]rst name is Simon Skinner.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE ROPER
dialogues.text: He’s in the loo!

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: Too much of Joyce’s lemonade perhaps. Laughter from the crowd. Thunder rumbles... ...We see a BLACK GLGVED HAND on a church door handle... ...The tombola spins. ANGEL looks at the clock... ...We see BLACK EOOTS race up belfry steps...  88. ...MESSENGER still waits. Sweat forms on his brow... ...ANGEL picks another name.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Tim Messenger.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: Tim, your number’s up. There’s much hub-bub. Thunder rumbles. Closer this time. ANGEL looks in the crowd frantically... .Unseen a CLOAKED EIGURE steps onto the church roof... . ANGEL jumps down off the makeshift stage. .ELACK GLOVED HANDS push on a loose turret stone. . TIM MESSENGER stands directly below... . ANGEL strides through the crowd... ...The gloved hand presses on the turret. The stone cracks... ...ANGEL breaks into a run. He reaches the churchyard... ...The stone breaks away from the roof and falls down. ...ANGEL runs in the churchyard, sees TIM MSSENGER- SPLAT. The tip of the stone CRUSHES MESSENGER’S head! ANGEL jerks back in horror. TIM MESSENGER now looks utter surreal, with an upside down cone where his head should b The off duty police arrive on the scene, along with many the NWA. SIMON SKINNER runs over from a chemical toilet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Keep back. There’s been a terrible accident! There’s much hub-bub and murmurs of the word ‘accident’ f the crowd. FISHER steps in, not having seen the body.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: What accident? (he sees it) Oh right. ANGEL grimaces, looks to the church roof and races off.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL runs up the church steps to the roof. He [U+FB02]in the door open and peers out. There’s no-one there. He comes back down to find all the off duty police waitin at the door, along with a troubled REV. SHOOTER.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nicholas, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Sir, I think all these deaths are linked. Tim Messenger was murdered.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: Who could do something like this?

dialogues.speaker: WAINNRIGHT
dialogues.text: Maybe it was the swan.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Apparently they can break a man’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Or blow up a man’s house.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Look-

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Whoa there Nicholas. Let me get this straight. Are you saying this is a crime scene?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I am.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Very well. Detectives, start interviewing everyone who was at the fete. Sgt Fisher, secure the area, PC Thatcher, get the CSI down here. PC Walker patrol the churchyard with Saxon. Nicholas, Danny...you know what to do.  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY sit in the rain at the crime scene. DANNY still wears his cowboy outfit and clutches the MONKEY.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do you really think this is murder?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I just don’t think we should rule it out.

dialogues.speaker: PC WALKER
dialogues.text: The ANDES Yeah. I think you’re right. passes with SAXON.

dialogues.speaker: WALKER
dialogues.text: Ifinkyertarkinaloodashitt.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He thinks you’re talking a load of shit. Swings and roundabouts innit? wander past. ANGEL and DANNY get up and approach.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Did you find anything?

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes I was extremely shocked when I looked at my watch and discovered the pubs were shut.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What about his house? Have you checked his office? Read his articles?

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: If you want to wade through every copy of the Sandford bloody Citizen, be our guest.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: It’s your job isn’t it? Detect!

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: This isn’t the city, Mister Angel. Not everyone’s a murdering psychopath. High time you realised that. You and your monkey.  The ANDES MONKEY. A furious 91. walk off into the night. DANNY holds up the CUDDLY

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Did he mean me or that? ANGEL puts his head in his hands. DANNY (cont’d) Maybe we should go home.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, there’s nothing going on is there?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Have you listened to anything I’ve said Constable?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Has anything I’ve told you in the last few weeks got through that thick skull of yours?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You said I could be an amazing policeman officer.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: There’s always something going on Danny and you’11 never be an amazing police officer until you understand that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I remembered something else you said.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: And what was that?  92.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You don’t know how to switch off. ANGEL stalks back to his stool and again guards the cordo He sits alone in the rain, soaking to the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL approaches his door. He unlocks it and enters. On t bed is the sodden CUDDLY MONKEY and a card reading - ‘This was left for you at reception. Regards Joyce’ ANGEL slumps into a chair, picks up the phone and dials-

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’m out of the office at present... ANGEL spies the Sandford Citizen featuring him on the cov He sees the byline ’Words and Pictures by Tim Messenger’. ANGEL hangs up and [U+FB02]icks through the paper, past mundane stories; ‘’Bypass Still Unannounced’, ’Sandford Family Trees’. He stops at a feature entitled ‘Sandford People’ with an accompanying photo of George Merchant. A quote reads "Thi is just the beginning; I have big plans for Sandford". AN looks inspired. He grabs his pen and notebook.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. LIERARY
dialogues.text: ANGEL sits at a table surrounded by archived volumes of t Sandford Citizen. He [U+FB02]ips through the pages at spe We see FLASHCUTS of ANGEL scouring articles, photocopying relevant pages, highlighting crucial sentences and even correcting the odd typo. It’s a blizzard of information. We see ANGEL highlight a sentence reading ’Mr. G. Merchan has applied for planning permission...’ We see another headline, ’George Of The Jungle: Merchant Buys Scrubland’ We see a photo of MARTIN BLOWER outside the Sandford Playhouse. The headline reads ’From Bar to Verse: Solicit Finances Drama Sociecy’. The pages [U+FB02]ip faster, the words start to blur. The has never been a more exciting scene in film history.  93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glum DANNY sits at a desk. ANGEL enters. DANNY doesn’t look up. ANGEL struggles with a guilty greeting.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Morning Constable.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Alright?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Thanks for the monkey.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s yours.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yeah but I won it for you. (smiles apologetically) Danny, I think I’m on to something.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I think with a little bit of deliberation we can figure out what links these deaths. ANGEL slaps a thick bundle of photocopies on the table.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I can’t do this by myself Danny. DANNY looks touched. The ANDES breeze past their desk.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Morning benders.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: What you up to?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nothing. The ANDES leave. ANGEL smiles at DANNY.  94.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Come on partner, lets go to work. FISHER pokes his head out of his office, a note in hand.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel. Someone from London rang for you.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Tell them I’11 ring ’em back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY and ANGEL walk their beat, striding in perfect time

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Tim Messenger.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Editor and journalist for The Sandford Citizen.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Fondness for puns.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Terrible speller.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Rut nevertheless had uncovered important information about...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SQUAD CAR
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY neglect their speed gun duty.  95.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: George Merchant.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Self made millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ch-ching.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Fancied himself as a property developer.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Had big plans for Sandford.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Pissed on the [U+FB02]oor in the Crown.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: But more importantly, was a good friend and client of...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. STREET
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY walk the beat again.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Martin Blower.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Affirmatron.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Respected solicitor and leading light of the local drama society.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Bad actor.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Undoubtedly.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Bad driver.  96.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Not necessarily.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Cheated on his missus.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Most certainly and we both know who with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY drive back to the sation.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Eve Draper.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Blower’s leading lady.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (Whistles)

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Distinctive laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Liked older men.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fingered.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: But crucially, where did she work?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Council.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Specifically?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The department of planning and development.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Where George Merchant had secured permission to build his dubious mansion on Norris Avenue.  97.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the office, the energy [U+FBO2]ags. DANNY has his head on ANGEL the table, ANGEL [U+FB02]icks endlessly thr his notes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Tim Messenger was onto something about George Merchant who was into something with Martin Blower who was up to something with Eve Draper.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: And Simon Skinner has something to do with it all.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But he runs the local supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I mean, maybe it was all accidents. People have accidents everyday. Gary Butcher drowned in his own septic tank the other week. ANGEL puts his head on the table too. FRANK swings by.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What are you two up to?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, look sharp. There’s been reports of a fire in the station.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What?! DORIS produces a cake with a single candle stuck in it. T other officers gather round, singing ‘Happy Birthday’. AN then notices cards and banners that have clearly been the the whole day. All reading ‘Happy Birthday Danny’.  98. ANGEL (cont’d) You should have said something.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We were working weren’t we? ANGEL is ashamed of himself. He slinks away to the door. DANNY (cont’d) Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Personal errand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squad car races along a street, lights [U+FBO2]ashing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL pulls up outside ’mourns as LESLIE’ and puts his notebook emphatically on the dashboard. ANGEL arrives at the door as LESLIE TILLER is shutting up

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Oh Miss Tiller, I was wondering, have you got any Peace Lilies?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: Of course. I was just about to pop off actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESLIE TILLER cuts wrapping paper with large garden shear

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: I can never find my scissors. Is this for someone special?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes it is. ANGEL spies packing crates and boxes on the [U+FBO2]oor. ANGEL (cont’d) Are you going somewhere Miss Tiller?  99.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: No. Well, yes. I’m moving away. It’s all a bit out of the blue. I was planning to disappear quietly actually. I do so hate goodbyes.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: And why the move, if you don’t mind me asking?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: Well, just between you and I... LESLIE TILLER seems a little edgy. ANGEL is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: You know that fella who blew up?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: George Merchant.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: That’s him, well George Merchant - god rest him - he wanted to buy this land, so he sends round his legal fella Martin Blower - god rest him - I thought I might take them up on it, because I’ve been thinking about moving for some time, I haven’t really got that much family round here, save for Cousin Sissy. And while the "Village Of The Year’ stuff is great and everything, I don’t really see anything from it, so I thought I might take them up on the offer and move to Buford Abbey. Would you like a card with this?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. You were saying about the offer?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER
dialogues.text: Well, it turns out that Martin Blower - god rest him - knew where the new bypass road is going because he was knocking off Eve Draper from the council - god rest her - then that reporter - god rest (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESLIE TILLER (cont'd) him - finds out about the route and tells me the land’s very valuable, ten times what George Merchant and Martin Blower - god rest them - offered me. So with them having passed on and me still owning the land, I decided to sell it on myself to some folks from the city that Martin, George and Eve - god rest the lot of them - had been talking to, apparently they want to build a big shopping centre or something, of course Cousin Sissy won’t be too happy about that, but as far as I’m concerned - ANGEL pats his pockets for his note book.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me for one second?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLEE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL leaves the [U+FBO2]orist. He runs back to the car t get his pocketbook. In the background we can see LESLIE TILLER wrapping the [U+FBO2]owers - but we can also see - The CLOAKED FIGURE slips in from the back room of the sho grabs the shears and plunges them into LESLIE TILLER’s throat. Blood spurts all over the counter and front windo ANGEL turns back to see...TILLER dead. Shears in her neck The blood. A SHADOW disappearing into the stock room...

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Stop. In the name of the law! ANGEL runs towards the [U+FB02]Jorist, throwing his truno at the window. It shatters a second before he jumps throu

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FLORIST/NURSERY
dialogues.text: ANGEL runs into the stock room, to see the CLOAKED FIGURE running through the aisles of the stock room. He gives chase. SMASH. The CLOAKED FIGURE jumps through a greenhouse wind catching their leg on the frame.  101. ANGEL is almost on top of him and jumps through the newly smashed window. Landing, he looks up to see the FIGURE no good 50 metres ahead, running towards a greenhouse and knocking garden furniture in its wake. ANGEL sprints off again, bursting into the greenhouse and gaining on the CLOAKED EIGUEE. Both knock plants asunder. The CLOAKED EIGURE slices through a mesh door with a knif and disappears over a hedge at the nursery perimeter. ANGEL reaches the final hedge to find the CLOAKED FIGURE, now 100 metres away, sprinting across a cricket pitch. A breathless ANGEL stands at the hedge, confused and amaz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the [U+FBO2]orist. ANGEL and FISHER stare at LESL TILLER who lies dead, shears protruding from her neck.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Hang about, hang about. You’re saying this wasn’t an accident?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE TILLER WAS MURDERED
dialogues.text: The assembled officers look at ANGEL as if he is insane.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: What just like Tim Messenger?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: And George Merchant?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: And Eve Draper? ANGEL scrawls on a piece of paper the word ‘YES’.  102.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: And Martin Blower?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, actually.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: COURSE HE FUCKING WAS
dialogues.text: DANNY pops a coin in the swearbox. ANGEL (cont’d) Thank you Danny.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh Murder. Murder. Murder. Change the fucking record. CARTWRIGHT pops a coin in the swearbox for WAINWRIGHT. WAINWRIGHT (cont’d) Thank you Andy.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Yes come on Sergeant, you’ve got to accept that it was another terrible accident.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting Leslie Tiller somehow tripped and fell on her own shears?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Ben Fletcher fell on his pitchfork the other week.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS THATCHER
dialogues.text: People have accidents everyday. What makes you think it was murder?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Because I was there.  103.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s a point. Why were you there?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I was buying a Japanese Peace Lily for Constable Butterman’s birthday.

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: What absolute horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Look, I chased a suspect from the scene. Innocent people don’t run.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: It might have been our old friend the cactus thief again.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS THATCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was a prickly customer. Everyone laughs. ANGEL crumples against the nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Am I going completely mad?

dialogues.speaker: WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Maybe you are?

dialogues.speaker: CAEIWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Ieah, maybe you killed her, seeing as you’re such a big fan of murder.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What !?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: YES....sir? FRANK ushers ANGEL into his office and shuts the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nicholas, Nicholas, Nicholas, what am I going to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Chief, you’ve got to understand-  104.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, you have to understand, the boys here aren’t used to the concepts you’re bandying about. (off Angel’s look) The ‘’M’ word, Nicholas. There hasn’t been a recorded murder in Sandford for 20 years.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: But I’m sure sir. And what’s more, I know who did it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not going to say who I think you’re going say. INT. SKINNER’S OFFICE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Could I see the manager please? ANGEL and co. burst into SKINNER’s office to find the CHECKOUT GIRL chewing gum. She intones into the tannoy.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT GIRL
dialogues.text: Mr. Skinner to the manager’s office please. Managers office. Mr. Skinner. INT. SKINNER’S GEFICE - NIGHT The cops are all crammed into the office. ANGEL stands purposefully. Various employees look through the office window.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel. Officers. To what do I owe this pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m arresting you on suspicion of the murder of Leslie Tiller.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Leslie Tiller is dead? How?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: She tripped and fell on her own shears. ANGEL throws a pen at FISHER’s head. He yelps.  105.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m also arresting you on suspicion of the murders of Tim Messenger on May ist, George Merchant on April 29th and Eve Draper and Martin Blower on April 28th.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Why on earth would I want to do that Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m glad you asked. The following is illustrated with oodles of FLASHCUTS. It looks pretty damn cool, for a British film. ANGEL (cont’d) My suspicions were [U+FBO2]rst aroused when you appeared at the scene of the Blower/Draper deaths, on the outskirts of Sandford, despite living and working in the centre of the village. I couldn’t help recall your comments at the theatre the previous evening, when you not only indicated your awareness of the couple’s affair but also inferred that Ms. Draper’s connections at the council might make her privy to important information. You yourself spoke of "bashing her head in". Perhaps hoping you might discover the route for the proposed Sandford Bypass. You were already suspicious that Blower’s client George Merchant was buying up an area of land on the edge of the village, after a story Tim Messenger ran in the Citizen. You put two and two together after noting Merchant’s use of your car park to visit Blower who you knew all too well had an inside connection at the council. The land Merchant was buying up had no particular value as it was but if it were to be made accessible by a new road, it would become an ideal location for perhaps, a retail park. Consumed with concern for your business and potential disloyalty from fickle customers (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL (cont’d) whom you yourself stated the desire to behead, you killed the potential competition in cold blood, staging the murders as accidents. You used a vehicle removal truck to stage the Blower/Draper crash and incinerated an old man in his house, covering your tracks with the judicial application of bacon and beans. However, there was a loose end. Tim Messenger foolishly confronted you at the village fete, after his own investigations lead him to the same conclusions. So you silenced him, before he could voice his concerns to me but not before he had told Leslie Tiller about the true value of her land. Upon discovering that she was about to sell up to the developers, you brutally murdered her with her own shears and made your escape utilising your impressive prize winning skills as a fun runner. ANGEL finishes his summation, by resting his hand on a ’f run’ trophy. The room is astonished. SKINNER claps slowly

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Very entertaining, Sergeant Angel. But I rather think you’ve been watching too many films.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He hasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Why would I kill Leslie? You clearly aren’t aware we’re related.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Oh but I am, ’Cousin Sissy’. ANGEL slaps down a photocopied sheet of a family tree article from the ’Sandford Citizen’. Highlighted are Skin and Tiller’s connected names. SKINNER scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: I’m afraid my nickname of Sissy is only a revelation to yourself. My teenage years studying ballet are well known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Sissy Skinner.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWEIGHT
dialogues.text: What a gaylord!

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Thank you Andrews. Despite my comment about beheading customers, what we here on Planet Sandford like to refer to as ’a joke’ I would personally relish the competition of another store. Anything to energise my workforce. SKINNEE gesticulates to his gormless minions

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You would relish the competition. Especially if it was yourself. As Miss Tiller’s only cousin, you’re set to inherit her land, on which you plan to build a Summeraisles Express. The perfect one stop shop for bypass traffic. ANGEL points to the sketch of a new store on

dialogues.speaker: SEINNER
dialogues.text: These sketches are just pipe dreams. Anyway, what makes you think I could dislodge part of the church roof? Or for that matter stage a car crash?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: It’s a well known fact that the church roof is severely in need of repair. As for the car, isn’t it true that two of your employees also operate the council’s vehicle removal truck? 107. outside. the wall. ANGEL points to the GRUFF LOOKING BUTCHERS. They are the same GRUFF LOOKING MEN from the removal vehicle earlier.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Sergeant, this is the 21st Century, I’1l think you find that many people hold down several jobs, I myself host a life drawing class at the Village Hall. (nods to Checkout Girl) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKINNER (cont’d) Tina here is a table dancer at Flappers.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: The thing is Mr. Skinner, you could quite easily have obtained access to the removal vehicle and used it for your own ends.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: These accusations are meaningless Sergeant, unless you can back them up with hard evidence.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Well you’ve certainly got me there. We’d need something conclusive. Like perhaps a wound you sustained on a shard of broken glass this very evening. ANGEL awkwardly pulls back SKINNER’s trouser legs. Nothin

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Oh Sergeant, this is getting to be embarrassing. Apart from anything else, how can I be in several places at once? I’m sure the store’s security footage can absolve me. Do feel free to spool through. INT. SKINNER’S OFFICE - NIGHT A frustrated ANGEL spools a huge pile of VHS tapes. We se CCTV images of SKINNER stagily strolling the shop [U+FBO2]oor. The other officers drift out of the office, grumbling. Soon only DANNY and FRANK remain. FRANK slaps a hand on ANGEL’s shoulder and leaves. DANNY picks up another tape.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I can handle this Danny You enjoy the rest of your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Did you really get me that plant?  109.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes, but it’s been impounded as evidence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe I can still water it. DANNY leaves as SKINNER apprcaches with LURCH.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Sergeant, I wanted you to know that if I do indeed now own the land belonging to Leslie, I intend to turn it into a memorial garden, in her honour.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (blows raspberry) Jog on.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Michael, will you escort the Sergeant off the premises when he’s quite finished?

dialogues.speaker: LURCH
dialogues.text: Yarp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL eats alone, a broken man. JOYCE serves him wine.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE CQOPER
dialogues.text: I can’t believe Leslie’s dead. How did it happen again?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: She tripped and fell on her own shears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL and DANNY are getting into uniform. Retrieving his cap, ANGEL sees the word ’TWAT’ written on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That wasn’t me.  110.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SQUAD CAR
dialogues.text: DANNY and ANGEL sit in their usual spot, as the high stre is being decorated with bunting. DANNY leeks at ANGEL, wh stares off intc space.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Look Nicholas. Mr. Treacher’s got his big coat on again...Want anything from the shop?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Cornetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY buys two ice-creams from a smirking ANNETTE ROPER. ANGEL watches on morosely.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE RUPER
dialogues.text: No luck catching them killers then?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s just the one killer actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY throws some change into the fountain. They get into the squad car, licking their ice creams. ANNETTE’S words echo in ANGEL’s head; ’No luck catching them killers then Licking his ice cream; ANGEL ponders DANNY’s response; ‘I just the one killer actually’. The words resonate. ANGEL stops eating his ice cream, his eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? You got brainfreeze?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No I got brainwave. Get us back to the station. Now! NANNY starts the car, whilst trying to finish as much of ice cream as he can. He clutches his head in pain.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Arrrgh!  111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squad car screeches to a halt in the car park.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: It’s more than one person.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: More than one killer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It was Skinner a minute ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Maybe it still is. Maybe he’s not alone. Maybe there are others.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who exactly?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know but we were buying Cornettos and it suddenly hit me-

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re an exceptional officer, Nicholas. Truly exceptional. But I’ve seen this before.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sergeant Popwell. It was exactly the same thing. You’ve come from a city where there’s danger round every corner and it’s driven you round the bend. ANGEL visibly sags. He becomes listless and compliant.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m due at a function in about half an hour. So do yourself a favour. Sleep on it. If you feel the same way in the morning, I give you my word, we’ll get right on it.  112.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Thank you sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL leaves the station. DANNY follows, confused.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What happened? what’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Nothing. I was just- I’m gonna go back and crash for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh okay. Need a lift?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: No, I could do with the walk. ANGEL walks off, feeling guilty. DANNY looks forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL trudges home, the street is festooned with bunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL slopes through the hotel reception. It is empty. A ROMEO AND JULIET poster shows understudies, Greg and Sher smiling as the male and female lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL takes out his key. He notices his door is ajar. The door [U+FB02]ies open...A huge CLOAKED FIGURE lifts A off the ground, throws him inside and slams the door behi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL hits the wall with a thud. He gets up and throws several punches at his attacker, but stops, clutching his injured hand. The FIGURE picks ANGEL up in a bear hug. AN struggles, pulling the assailant’s hood off to reveal-  113. LURCH. They look at each other for a second. ANGEL brings his [U+FB02]sts down on either side of LURCH’s head. LURC drops ANGEL, holding his ears. ANGEL kicks LURCH in the balls. He barely winces before hurling ANGEL across the r into a painting of the castle. His notebook drops to the [U+FBO2]oor. LUNCH lumbers towards him. ANGEL grabs the CUDDLY MONKEY looks throws it in LURCH’s direction. LUNCH catches it an is momentarily charmed, hypnotised by the monkey’s cute eyes. A whistle from offscreen. LURCH turns to see ANGEL uprigh brandishing his beloved POT PLANT.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Playtime’s over. SMASH. ANGEL hits LURCH across the head, destroying his Peace Lily in the process. LURCH drops. His walkie-talkie clatters to the [U+FB02]oor, crackling to life.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Michael? Michael? Are you there? Michael? Is everything okay? ANGEL speaks into the Walkie-talkie in a thick brogue.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yarp.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sergeant Angel has been taken care of?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yarp.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s not going to get back up again?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: ...Narp?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Good. Proceed to the castle. ANGEL looks to a castle painting on the wall. He pulls ou his phone and dials.  114.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You’ve reached Frank Butterman. Please leave a message after the beep-

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Frank. This shit just got real. Skinner just tried to kill me. He’s going somewhere. The castle I think. I’m going there now. I don’t know who to trust. It’s Nicholas by the way. ANGEL turns to see DANNY at the door and jumps a mile. DA looks at LURCH sprawled among the pot plant debris.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh my god. What happened to your Peace Lily?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Danny. Stay here. Watch him. Call your Dad. Tell him I was right.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m going to bust this thing wide open.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nicholas? Danny picks up ANGEL’s notebook and puts it in his pocket

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Thanks partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGEL runs down the high street past a National Trust sig pointing toward ‘SANDFORD CASTLE’.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CASTLE RUINS
dialogues.text: ANGEL approaches Sandford Castle ruins, a dilapidated 12t Century Castle. It looks spooky in the dark. ANGEL hears voices coming from inside. We hear chanting-  115.

dialogues.speaker: MASSED VOICES
dialogues.text: .bonum commune communitatis... ANGEL peers into the main hall. He sees several BLACK CLOAKED FIGURES standing around a large circular stone tablet. They hold torches under their faces. ANGEL makes out familiar faces under the hoods. We see TO WEAVER, whose words echo in ANGEL’s head; "I can see what the entire village is up to..." ANGEL looks to see 12 walkie talkies on the stone tablet "Got everyone linked up with a walkie so we can keep each other abreast of any misadventure." ANGEL sees SKINNER under one of the hoods. Words echo; "H can I be in several places at once?"... We see ELASHCUTS of the [U+FBO2]orist chase, now with ang that we didn’t see previously; a second CLOAKED FIGURE outside the greenhouse, a third CLOAKED EIGUEE behind the hedge. ANGEL spies some of the other faces - JOYCE COOPER, ANNET

dialogues.speaker: ROPER, JAMES READER, REV. SHOOTER, DR. HATCHER, AMANDA PA
dialogues.text: - "We’re basically a group of volunteers who strive to ke the village just so. ANGEL’s thoughts [U+FBO2]ash back to the fountain. We see DANNY throw some change in. The penny drops. We see the plaque; ’This fountain was generously restored with funds raised by F. Butterman, J. Cooper, R. Hatcher, A. Paver.. As the CLOAKED FIGURES stop chanting and sit at the table ANGEL is even more horrified by what he hears next...

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE COOPER
dialogues.text: Quick announcement before we begin. Janet Barker has decided to call her boys Roger and Martin which is lovely. The christening will be Saturday week and all are welcome. Tom? The CLOAKED FIGURES all swing their torches to WEAVER.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Thanks Joyce. Now you’1l be pleased to know that the tenacious Sergeant Angel has now been taken care of. Thanks must go to Simon Skinner for his efforts in this. Our very own Joyce Cooper will discover the officer tomorrow morning, slumped (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEAVER (cont’d) on the wet [U+FBO2]oor of his ensuite bathroom, having slipped in the shower and tragically broken his neck. Dr. Hatcher will take it from there.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCHER
dialogues.text: Indeed and may I say very well executed Simon. I will of course pronounce the death as accidental. That is after all what I’m here for. All torches to DR. HATCHER. There are mild chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: With Sergeant Angel dispatched, we can concentrate our efforts on eradicating our hoodie infestation, after which nothing will stand in our way.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh I beg to differ, Mister Weaver. All the torches spin to the direction of the voice.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, well, well, I see we have visitors. ANGEL walks into the torch beams, warrant card aloft.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Sergeant Nicholas Angel. Sandford Police Service.

dialogues.speaker: SNINNER
dialogues.text: My, he is tenacious isn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I’m placing you all under arrest on suspicion of conspiracy to commit murder.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: Oh come, come Sergeant Angel.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed of yourselves. This is supposed to be the community that cares!  There’s a 117.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: Oh, but we do care Nicholas.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE COOPER
dialogues.text: It’s all about the greater good.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: The greater good.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean the greater good?

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: The greater good.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Sandford, Nicholas. The village.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCHER
dialogues.text: A happy village is a healthy village.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: Perfection breeds contentment and contentment is paramount.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: You see, as much as I enjoyed your wild theories Sergeant, the truth is far less complex. Blower’s fate was simply the result of his being an appalling actor. murmur of "appalling".

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You murdered him for that?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: He murdered Bill Shakespeare.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What!? Oh I see. We see FLASHEACKS of MARTIN ELOWER’s dressing room murder Now, we see new angles with MULTIPLE CLOAKED FIGURES.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: The Sandford Players is an important feather in our cap.  118.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCEER
dialogues.text: We couldn’t let Blower jeopardize that. Not when we had two semimprofessionals waiting in the wings. SKINNER points to an OLDER COUPLE in cloaks who wave back

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Let us not forget Greg was an extra in Straw Dogs -

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I know!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE COQPER
dialogues.text: Martin was less concerned with the reputation of the village than his sordid affair with Eve Draper. We see FLASHBACKS of EVE’s murder by MULTIPLE KILLERS.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: And so Eve deserved to die too?

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCHER
dialogues.text: She did have an annoying laugh. There’s a murmur of ‘annoying’.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: And George Merchant?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: He had an awful house. There’s a murmur of "awful". We see FLASHBACKS of MERCHANT’S ‘accidental’ explosion. N with MULTIPLE CLOAKED FIGURES engineering it.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE COOPER
dialogues.text: We begged him in vain to make his residence more in keeping with the village’s rustic aesthetic.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What was Messenger’s crime?

dialogues.speaker: SNINNER
dialogues.text: Tim Messenger’s tenure as editor of the Sandford Citizen has been unbearable.  119.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: Our once great paper had become riddled with tabloid journalism and dreadful punnery. Not to mention persistent errors.

dialogues.speaker: ROY PORTER
dialogues.text: He listed her age as 55.

dialogues.speaker: MARY PORTER
dialogues.text: When I’m actually 53.

dialogues.speaker: REV SHOOTER
dialogues.text: The church roof was in need of repair and the insurers wouldn’t pay unless it was certified hazardous. Let’s just say we killed two birds with one stone. FLASHBACK of MULTIPLE CLOAKED FIGURES pushing the turret.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: What about Leslie Tillar? One of your own? Her her horticultural expertise helped put Sandford on the map.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE COOPER
dialogues.text: She was ever so good.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER
dialogues.text: Cousin Leslie was a terrible shame. But it seems she was set on moving away.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: We had to stop her before she shared her green fingers with anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE COOPER
dialogues.text: Not least the heathens at Euford Abbey. The NWA simultaneously spit on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HATCHER
dialogues.text: If we can’t have her no-one can.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: How can this be for the greater good?!  120.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: The greater good.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Shut it. These people died for no reason, no reason whatsoever?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh I wouldn’t say that. All torches move to the voice. To ANGEL’s horror, it is FRANK. He wears the era FASHIONED POLICE CAPE.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I was like you once Nicholas. I believed in the immutable word of the law. That is until the night Mrs. Butterman was taken from me. You see, no-one loved Sandford more than her. She was head of the Women’s Institute, chair of the ’[U+FB02]oral committee’, even ran the Neighbourhood Watch before Tom. When they started the ’Village of the Year’ contest, she worked round the clock, it became her life. I’ve never seen such dedication. On the eve of the adjudicator’s arrival, some travellers moved into Callahan Park. Before could say gypsy scum, We were knee deep in dog muck, thieving kids and crusty jugglers. We lost the title and Irene lost her mind. She drove her Datsun Cherry into Sandford Gorge. The inquiry said it was an accident but I knew better. From that moment on I swore that I’d do her proud. And whatever the cost, we’d make Sandford great again.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Sir, this doesn’t make sense.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER
dialogues.text: It makes perfect sense, Sergeant. Frank gathered together a group of the most faithful Sandfordians and showed us how we might rid our streets of the paedophiles and perverts-  121.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SHOOTER REAPER
dialogues.text: -the shoplifters- -the shirtlifters-

dialogues.speaker: WEAVER AMANDA PAVER
dialogues.text: -the punks, the drunks- -the thugs, the mugs-

dialogues.speaker: SKINNER REV. SHOOTER
dialogues.text: -the hams, the shams- -the drifters, the grifters-
